question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the matrix $\mathbf{P}$ such that for any vector $\mathbf{v},$ $\mathbf{P} \mathbf{v}$ is the projection of $\mathbf{v}$ onto the $yz$-plane.
inference:
The projection of $\mathbf{v}$ onto the $yz$-plane is the vector $\mathbf{v}_p$ that lies in the $yz$-plane and has the same length as $\mathbf{v}$. The vector $\mathbf{v}_p$ can be written as $\mathbf{v}_p = \left<0, v_2, v_3\right>$, where $v_2$ and $v_3$ are the $y$- and $z$-coordinates of $\mathbf{v}$, respectively.

The matrix $\mathbf{P}$ that projects $\mathbf{v}$ onto the $yz$-plane is the matrix that transforms $\mathbf{v}$ into $\mathbf{v}_p$. This matrix is given by

$$\mathbf{P} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}.$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.

The matrix $\mathbf{P}$ that projects $\mathbf{v}$ onto the $yz$-plane is the matrix that transforms $\mathbf{v}$ into $\mathbf{v}_p$. This matrix is given by

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.
